SafetyInspectionBy: Mecklenburg County Land Use & Env. Svs.

_exec_summary.SummaryText: The Motiva Enterprises, LLC - Charlotte (North) Terminal complies with the National Fire Protection Association #58 (2004 Edition) for Liquified Petroleum Gas Storage, and it is this Facility's policy to notify the Charlotte Fire Department (Box Response including Stations 21, 13, 25, 33 and Battalion Chief 6) and Mecklenburg County Emergency Management via the "911" service in the event of an emergency and follow all additional response procedures set forth in the Facility's Integrated Contingency Plan, as appropriate.  Medical emergencies will require notification of the Carolinas Medical Center and associated ambulance service via 911.  The Facility currently maintains a trained incipient stage fire and hazardous material emergency response team to respond to small or initial stages of an emergency.  The Motiva Enterprises, LLC - Charlotte (North) Terminal transfers/stores refined product (regular/premium gasoline and diesel fuel) and handles product additives, including the liquified butane blending system (direct injection into refined product pipelines to the truck loading rack).  The Risk Management Program covers the butane blending system including the associated piping, 1 x 60,000 gallon vessel, the blending skid, sampling unit (Bartec-Benke), and the truck offloading station product connection point.    The Facility's worst case scenario is the catastrophic failure of the blending system's 60,000 gallon liquified (pressure) butane vessel when filled to the greatest amount allowed (fill shutoff device at 85% with an alarm at 80%) resulting in a vapor cloud explosion.  This is the recommended scenario based on the EPA Guidance Document and RMP Comp.  The facility's alternate scenario ([unlikely] resulting in a substantive release based on discussion with Texon/MCE and terminal personnel) is a Boiling Liquid Expanding Vapor Explosion (BLEVE) resulting in an explosion and associated fireball.  Other alternatives considered included pump failure, liquid butane

pipe failure and truck pull-away.  These scenarios were either considered highly unlikely or resulted in less of an impact.
  
The Motiva Enterprises LLC - Charlotte (North) Terminal complies with the U.S. Environmental Protection Agency's Accident Prevention Rules (40 CFR Part 68) and the U.S. Department of Labor - Occupational Safety and Health Administration Process Safety Regulations (29CFR Part 1910.119).  The butane blending system is designed, constructed, and maintained to meet or exceed the NFPA #58 requirements for Liquified Petroleum Gas Storage.  To this date, this Facility has never had an accident involving the butane blending system resulting in dealths, injuries, property/environmental damage, evacuations or sheltering in-place.  In the event of an emergency involving the Charlotte (North) Terminal butane blending system, it is the policy of the Facility to initially contact the Charlotte Fire Department and request their assistance.  The Facility maintains a trained (annually) incipient fire and hazardous materials emergency response team, as referenced above.  The Facility's emergency response plans are coordinated with the Charlotte Fire Department and the Mecklenburg County Emergency Management.  The Charlotte Fire Department, which maintains a full hazardous material response team (HazMat II), is aware of the Facility's butane blending system, access via Tom Sadler Road, and available fire suppression equipment including approximately fifteen 20lb. ABC fire extinguishers, and water sources (two hydrants available adjacent to the Terminal with a total flow of approximately 2,210 gpm).  Motiva Enterprises, LLC Charlotte (North) Terminal maintains a vegetation control program to minimize plant growth within 10 feet of the system.

The general accidental release prevention program and the specific prevention steps:

The Facility complies with 40 CFR Part 68 of the EPA and with all applicable State codes and regulations.  The Facility Butane Blendin

g Process is designed and constructed in accordance with NFPA 58, and additionally complies with 29 CFR Part 1910.119 (Process Safety Management for Highly Hazardous Chemicals) and the U.S. Department of Homeland Security Chemical Facility Anti-Terrorism Standard.

Five-year accident history:

This RMP is for an existing butane blending process (initiated in approximately January 2008); there have been no accidents/incidents since the onset of operations as reported by the Charlotte North Terminal.

The emergency response program:

Response actions are coordinated with the Charlotte Fire Department and Mecklenburg County Emergency Management.  An Integrated Contingency Plan (ICP) is in place to inform employees what to do in case of a release, fire, medical emergency, etc., and to notify emergency responders when there is a need for a response.

Planned changes to improve safety:

Motiva Enterprises, LLC has identified an overall PSM/RMP facility coordinator to integrate uniform procedures between Motiva sites.  Additionally, the Charlotte North Terminal intends to facilitate further interaction and training with the local and county emergency responders.

The Charlotte North Terminal intends to involve the local emergency services to participate in system awareness training on or about the time of startup and emergency response exercises moving forward.
